DataElement.preferredName: Karnofsky Performance Status First Cancer Diagnosis Timepoint Score
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Result of a Karnofsky Performance status (KPS) at the time of a person's initial cancer diagnosis.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Karnofsky Performance Status First Cancer Diagnosis Timepoint
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Karnofsky Performance Status. A standard way of measuring the ability of cancer patients to perform ordinary tasks.  The scores range from 0 to 100, with a higher score indicating a better ability to carry out daily activities.  KPS may be used to determine a patient's prognosis, to measure changes in functioning, or to decide if a patient could be included in a clinical trial._Preceding all others in time or space or degree._A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004_The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation._A specific point in the time continuum, including those established relative to an event.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Karnofsky Performance Status. A standard way of measuring the ability of cancer patients to perform ordinary tasks.  The scores range from 0 to 100, with a higher score indicating a better ability to carry out daily activities.  KPS may be used to determine a patient's prognosis, to measure changes in functioning, or to decide if a patient could be included in a clinical trial.

Concepts.definition: An index designed for classifying patients 16 years of age or older by their functional impairment.

Property.preferredDefinition: Preceding all others in time or space or degree.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.:A specific point in the time continuum, including those established relative to an event.

Concepts.definition: Preceding all others in time or space or degree.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.
A specific point in the time continuum, including those established relative to an event.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A numeric score measure of the Karnofsky Performance status scale, representing the functional capabilities of a person.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Added OBIB alternate name and identifier DWQ 03-21-2019

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A standard way of measuring the ability of cancer patients to perform ordinary tasks. The Karnofsky Performance scores range from 0 to 100. A higher score means the patient is better able to carry out daily activities. KPS may be used to determine a patient's prognosis, to measure changes in a patient's ability to function, or to decide if a patient could be included in a clinical trial.:A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

Concepts.definition: An index designed for classifying patients 16 years of age or older by their functional impairment.
A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.
